title: Slow wind repowering risks Spain’s green targets – industry
subtitle: (Montel) Spain’s 2030 green targets are at risk due to permitting delays slowing down the repowering of its wind fleet, energy industry leaders told Montel.
body:
The country would need to add almost 30 GW of wind capacity to meet its target of 62 GW by 2030, with repowering considered key to this. Of this 30 GW, 10-12 GW should come from capacity added to existing plants after repowering, according to government plans.
However, long permitting times were hampering progress, said Heikki Willstedt, director of energy policy and climate change at Spanish lobby Wind Energy Association (AEE).
“Repowering could be a good business in Spain but there is no regulatory framework to facilitate it,” he added.
Spain was among the countries that failed to enact an EU directive to streamline permitting for repowering renewable plants, potentially limiting administrative deadlines to 12 months, Willstedt said. 
Spain has until May to apply this EU legislation, which would reduce permitting times “from four years to just one”, said Javier Pamos, product manager at Aurora Energy Research in Spain.
Its neighbour Portugal had already simplified permitting for repowering plants, he said, which had “significantly” sped up the process.
“Numbers don’t add up”As well as administrative hurdles, the pace of repowering in Spain has been slow as the “numbers don’t add up from an economic standpoint”, said Marta Fernandez Bordon, business development director at Spanish utility Acciona.
The wind sector would need specific auctions for repowering or long-term support to cover part of the costs, she added.
The Spanish government in 2023 announced EUR 148m in aid for wind repowering, but this will only allow 557 MW of capacity. 
The business case for repowering wind assets was also hampered by high interest rates, increased operating costs and logistical hurdles, said Willstedt.
